page.title: 13Early 20th Century Ayr.
page.content: { Holmston}School, where I went, was founded in 1885 for the education of the poor. Lessons were on slate _ there were no buses, everyone walked _ dinner was a carried piece. I got a penny for fetching the Master's dinner and spent it in Corbett's sweet shop. Next door was Watson's grocery and a fishmonger. Apart from Hourston's haberdashery the{High Street}was tene_ ments. Attitudes to clothes nowadays are vastly different and relaxed _ no high button boots and starched petti_ coats. {Holiday visitors}came to Ayr in thousands by train and steamer. Entertainment would be a band on the {Low Green,}a pierrot concert in the {Town Hall}or a visit to{Bolton's Tent {Theatre.} Sunday afternoon outing was by tram to Banks O' Doon Tearoom or Belleisle. Rowing boats were hired for a penny at{North Harbour Wall.
